title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 21 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Chronicles chapter 21 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 21 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Chronicles Chapter 21.

questions.question: Who stood up against Israel and provoked David to number Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Satan
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:1 states that Satan stood up against Israel and provoked David to number Israel.

questions.question: To whom did David give the command to number Israel?
options: Joab and the rulers of the people
questions.correctAnswer: Joab and the rulers of the people
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:2 shows David commanding Joab and the rulers to number Israel.

questions.question: What was Joab's response when David ordered him to number Israel?
options: The LORD make his people an hundred times so many more
I will do as you command without question
The people are too few to number
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD make his people an hundred times so many more
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:3 records Joab's answer wishing blessings on Israel and questioning David's command.

questions.question: How many men of Israel who drew sword were numbered according to Joab's report?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:5 says all Israel numbered 1,100,000 men who drew sword.

questions.question: Which two tribes were not counted in the numbering by Joab?
questions.correctAnswer: Levi and Benjamin
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:6 states that Levi and Benjamin were not counted among the numbered men.

questions.question: What was God's reaction to David numbering Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: God was displeased
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:7 clearly says God was displeased with this thing.

questions.question: What did David say to God after he realized his sin?
options: I have sinned greatly; do away with my iniquity
Let me number the people again
questions.correctAnswer: I have sinned greatly; do away with my iniquity
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:8 records David confessing his great sin and asking God to remove his iniquity.

questions.question: Who was the seer sent by the LORD to speak to David?
questions.correctAnswer: Gad
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:9 identifies Gad as David's seer who spoke for the LORD.

questions.question: What choice did the LORD offer David through Gad?
options: Three years' famine, or three months of sword, or three days of pestilence
Peace or war, riches or poverty
questions.correctAnswer: Three years' famine, or three months of sword, or three days of pestilence
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:12 gives the three options offered by the LORD to David through Gad.

questions.question: Which punishment did David choose to fall into the hand of?
questions.correctAnswer: The hand of the LORD
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:13 shows David choosing to fall into the hand of the LORD because of His mercies rather than men.

questions.question: How many men died in Israel because of the pestilence sent by the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Seventy thousand
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:14 states that seventy thousand men died because of the pestilence.

questions.question: Where did the angel of the LORD stand with a drawn sword over Jerusalem?
questions.correctAnswer: Between earth and heaven
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:16 describes the angel standing between earth and heaven with a drawn sword over Jerusalem.

questions.question: Who did David ask to grant him the threshingfloor to build an altar?
questions.correctAnswer: Ornan the Jebusite
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:22 shows David asking Ornan to grant the threshingfloor for an altar.

questions.question: True or False: Joab was eager and willing to number all the people as commanded by David without question.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:3 shows Joab questioning David's command and calling it a cause of trespass, indicating reluctance.

questions.question: True or False: David paid Ornan the full price for the threshingfloor to build the altar.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:24-25 states David insisted on paying full price to Ornan for the place.

medium.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 21 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Chronicles Chapter 21 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with temptation to rely on numbers and human strength rather than trusting God. Based on 1 Chronicles 21, what biblical truth about faith and obedience would you share?
options: Trusting God is more important than relying on numbers or human strength
Counting people is a good way to measure God's blessing
God encourages us to boast in our military power
Using numbers shows faith in God's provision
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God is more important than relying on numbers or human strength
questions.explanation: In 1 Chronicles 21:1-4, Satan provokes David to number Israel, which displeased God (v7). Joab even questions the king's command as causing trespass (v3). This teaches us that faith and trust in God supersede reliance on human strength or numbers.

questions.question: How does David's response to his sin in numbering Israel teach us about humility and repentance?
options: David admits his sin and asks God to remove the iniquity
David blames Joab for the sin
David justifies his actions as wise
questions.correctAnswer: David admits his sin and asks God to remove the iniquity
questions.explanation: David confesses his great sin and pleads with God to remove the iniquity of His servant (v8). This shows humility and a heart of repentance, important for believers facing trials (v17).

questions.question: A believer is facing consequences from a poor decision. What can they learn from David’s choice when offered three punishments by God?
options: Trust in God’s mercy and choose to fall into His hands rather than man’s
Avoid consequences by bargaining with God
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God’s mercy and choose to fall into His hands rather than man’s
questions.explanation: David chose to fall into the hand of the LORD because His mercies are great, rather than the hand of man (v13). This teaches trusting God's mercy even during hardship.

questions.question: What does Joab’s hesitation to number Israel reveal about integrity and obedience in leadership?
options: Joab respects God’s will and questions the king’s order as possibly sinful
Joab refuses to obey at all
questions.correctAnswer: Joab respects God’s will and questions the king’s order as possibly sinful
questions.explanation: Joab questions the king’s command (v3), showing a discernment between obedience to human authority and God’s will. Leaders must balance obedience with integrity and spiritual wisdom.

questions.question: How does David’s willingness to pay full price for the threshingfloor teach us about honesty and stewardship?
options: David insists on paying the full price and not taking what belongs to Ornan for free
David accepts the gift without payment
David takes the threshingfloor by force
questions.correctAnswer: David insists on paying the full price and not taking what belongs to Ornan for free
questions.explanation: David refuses to take the threshingfloor or offerings without cost (v24), demonstrating integrity, respect for others’ property, and faithful stewardship in worship.

questions.question: When David saw the angel with a drawn sword over Jerusalem, how did he and the elders respond, and what does this teach about humility and prayer in times of crisis?
options: They fell on their faces in sackcloth, showing humility and seeking God’s mercy
They ignored the angel and continued their work
They fled the city in fear
questions.correctAnswer: They fell on their faces in sackcloth, showing humility and seeking God’s mercy
questions.explanation: David and the elders clothed in sackcloth fell on their faces (v16), a biblical posture of repentance and prayer, teaching believers to seek God humbly when facing trials.

questions.question: True or False: God was pleased with David’s decision to number Israel and rewarded him for it.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The text clearly states God was displeased with the numbering and smote Israel as a consequence (v7). This teaches obedience to God's commands over personal desires.

questions.question: True or False: The site where David built the altar was purchased to demonstrate respect and reverence for God's house.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: David paid six hundred shekels of gold for the threshingfloor (v25), showing respect and reverence by not taking it as a gift (v24), teaching believers the value of honoring God with integrity.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: David’s prayer asking God not to punish the people but to lay the plague on him and his family teaches us about ______.
questions.correctAnswer: intercession and self-sacrifice
questions.explanation: David intercedes for the people and offers himself and his family as the ones to bear punishment (v17), exemplifying Christlike love and responsibility.

questions.question: How does the angel of the LORD’s action and God’s response to stop destruction teach us about God’s mercy and justice?
options: God showed mercy by stopping the angel’s destruction when enough was done
God was indifferent to Israel’s punishment
questions.correctAnswer: God showed mercy by stopping the angel’s destruction when enough was done
questions.explanation: God saw the angel destroying Jerusalem and told him to stop (v15,27), teaching that God is just but merciful, willing to relent when repentance occurs.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to take shortcuts in their service to God. What principle does David’s building of the altar and offering sacrifices at Ornan’s threshingfloor teach?
options: Offerings to God should be made with sincerity, cost, and obedience
God accepts any offering regardless of heart
Sacrifices can be done without God’s command
God prefers offerings given for free
questions.correctAnswer: Offerings to God should be made with sincerity, cost, and obedience
questions.explanation: David built the altar and offered sacrifices after paying full price and following God’s command (v18-26), showing that worship requires sincerity and obedience.

questions.question: Based on David’s fear of the sword of the angel of the LORD, what can believers learn about reverence and awe before God’s holiness?
options: Fear and reverence before God's holiness is appropriate and leads to seeking His guidance
God’s holiness is irrelevant to daily life
Fear of God means avoidance and hiding
questions.correctAnswer: Fear and reverence before God's holiness is appropriate and leads to seeking His guidance
questions.explanation: David was afraid because of the angel’s sword and could not approach to inquire of God (v30), teaching reverence for God's holiness and the importance of seeking Him rightly.

questions.question: What does Gad’s role as David’s seer and messenger teach about spiritual counsel and seeking God’s direction?
options: Believers should seek godly counsel and be open to God’s guidance through others
Counsel should be based on personal opinion
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should seek godly counsel and be open to God’s guidance through others
questions.explanation: Gad delivered God’s message and options to David (v9-12,18-19), showing the importance of seeking and following godly counsel in decision-making.

questions.question: How does the inclusion of specific numbers of soldiers in Israel and Judah teach about honesty and transparency in leadership?
options: Accurate reporting and transparency are important, but must align with God’s will
Leaders should exaggerate numbers for pride
Joab refused to report any numbers
questions.correctAnswer: Accurate reporting and transparency are important, but must align with God’s will
questions.explanation: Joab gave an accurate count (v5), but the act displeased God (v7). This teaches that honesty is vital, yet leadership must also be submitted to God’s guidance.

questions.question: What does the fact that Levi and Benjamin were not counted teach us about God’s priorities in His people?
options: Spiritual roles and God’s purposes can differ from worldly measures
All people should be counted equally for power
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual roles and God’s purposes can differ from worldly measures
questions.explanation: Levi and Benjamin were excluded from the count because the king’s word was abominable to Joab (v6), showing that God values spiritual roles beyond mere numbers.

hard.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 21 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Chronicles Chapter 21.

questions.question: What was Satan's role in the events of 1 Chronicles 21?
options: He stood up against Israel and provoked David to number Israel
He directly caused the pestilence upon Israel
He advised David to build an altar to the LORD
He appeared as an angel with a drawn sword
questions.correctAnswer: He stood up against Israel and provoked David to number Israel
questions.explanation: According to 1 Chronicles 21:1, Satan stood up against Israel and provoked David to number Israel, initiating the events described in the chapter.

questions.question: Why did Joab hesitate to carry out David's command to number Israel?
options: He feared it would be a cause of trespass to Israel
He was loyal to another king
He was physically unable to conduct the census
He wanted to number only Judah
questions.correctAnswer: He feared it would be a cause of trespass to Israel
questions.explanation: Joab expressed concern that numbering Israel would cause sin or trespass to the people, as stated in 1 Chronicles 21:3.

questions.question: What was the total number of men who drew the sword in Israel according to Joab’s census?
options: One thousand thousand and one hundred thousand
questions.correctAnswer: One thousand thousand and one hundred thousand
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:5 records that Joab counted one thousand thousand and one hundred thousand men who drew the sword in Israel.

questions.question: Which tribes did Joab exclude from the census and why?
options: Levi and Benjamin, because the king's word was abominable to Joab
Judah and Dan, because they were too small
Naphtali and Gad, due to geographical difficulties
Reuben and Simeon, because they were not counted in previous censuses
questions.correctAnswer: Levi and Benjamin, because the king's word was abominable to Joab
questions.explanation: Joab did not count Levi and Benjamin as he found the king's command to number the people abominable (1 Chronicles 21:6).

questions.question: What three punishments did God offer David through Gad?
options: Three years' famine, three months of defeat by enemies, or three days of pestilence
Ten years of drought, a plague of locusts, or exile from Jerusalem
Loss of the kingdom, blindness, or death
Three days of darkness, famine, or sword against the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: Three years' famine, three months of defeat by enemies, or three days of pestilence
questions.explanation: Gad relayed God's offer to David of three choices: three years' famine, three months before enemies' sword, or three days of pestilence (1 Chronicles 21:12).

questions.question: How did David respond to the options presented by Gad?
options: He preferred to fall into the hands of the LORD rather than men
He chose the three years' famine
He chose to be destroyed by enemies
He refused to choose and asked for more time
questions.correctAnswer: He preferred to fall into the hands of the LORD rather than men
questions.explanation: David expressed a preference to be in the hands of the LORD because of His great mercy rather than in the hands of men (1 Chronicles 21:13).

questions.question: How many men died from the pestilence sent upon Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Seventy thousand
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:14 states that seventy thousand men died due to the pestilence sent by the LORD.

questions.question: Where did the angel of the LORD stand with a drawn sword over Jerusalem?
options: At the threshingfloor of Ornan the Jebusite
At the high place of Gibeon
At the tabernacle in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: At the threshingfloor of Ornan the Jebusite
questions.explanation: The angel of the LORD stood by the threshingfloor of Ornan the Jebusite with a drawn sword over Jerusalem as described in 1 Chronicles 21:15-16.

questions.question: What did David do when he saw the angel of the LORD with a drawn sword?
options: Fell on his face with the elders, clothed in sackcloth
Called for the priests to offer sacrifices
Sent Joab to stop the angel
questions.correctAnswer: Fell on his face with the elders, clothed in sackcloth
questions.explanation: David and the elders of Israel, clothed in sackcloth, fell on their faces when they saw the angel of the LORD (1 Chronicles 21:16).

questions.question: In David's prayer, who did he ask God to place the punishment upon?
options: David himself and his father's house
questions.correctAnswer: David himself and his father's house
questions.explanation: David asked God to let the punishment fall on him and his father's house rather than on the people (1 Chronicles 21:17).

questions.question: What command did the angel of the LORD give to Gad regarding David?
options: To instruct David to build an altar on Ornan's threshingfloor
To tell David to flee Jerusalem
To order David to number the people again
To command David to gather the armies
questions.correctAnswer: To instruct David to build an altar on Ornan's threshingfloor
questions.explanation: The angel commanded Gad to tell David to set up an altar to the LORD on the threshingfloor of Ornan the Jebusite (1 Chronicles 21:18).

questions.question: How did Ornan respond when David asked to buy the threshingfloor?
options: He offered it freely, including oxen and wheat
He asked David to build the altar elsewhere
questions.correctAnswer: He offered it freely, including oxen and wheat
questions.explanation: Ornan offered the place and all the needed items as a gift to David (1 Chronicles 21:23).

questions.question: Why did David insist on paying the full price for Ornan's threshingfloor?
options: Because he would not offer burnt offerings that cost him nothing
Because he wanted to show his wealth
Because Ornan refused to give it freely
Because it was customary for kings to pay full price
questions.correctAnswer: Because he would not offer burnt offerings that cost him nothing
questions.explanation: David refused Ornan's free offer and insisted on paying full price so that the offerings would be acceptable to the LORD (1 Chronicles 21:24).

questions.question: What was the result when David built the altar and offered sacrifices on the threshingfloor?
options: The LORD answered him by fire from heaven on the altar
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD answered him by fire from heaven on the altar
questions.explanation: God responded to David’s sacrifice by fire from heaven, showing acceptance of the offering (1 Chronicles 21:26).

questions.question: True or False: David was able to personally inquire of God at the tabernacle in Gibeon during this time.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: David could not go before the tabernacle at Gibeon to inquire of God because he feared the sword of the angel of the LORD (1 Chronicles 21:30).

theological.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 21 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Chronicles Chapter 21 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who provoked David to number Israel according to 1 Chronicles 21?
questions.correctAnswer: Satan
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:1 states that Satan stood up against Israel and provoked David to number Israel, highlighting the reality of spiritual opposition. This aligns with Job 1:6-12 where Satan challenges God's people, and the New Testament confirms Satan's role as adversary (1 Peter 5:8).

questions.question: What was Joab's initial response to David's command to number Israel?
options: He questioned the necessity and warned against it
He refused to count the Levites
He suggested a census of only Judah
questions.correctAnswer: He questioned the necessity and warned against it
questions.explanation: In 1 Chronicles 21:3, Joab questions David's command, implying that numbering the people could lead to sin. This reflects the biblical concern that pride and self-reliance can accompany such actions (Exodus 30:12; 2 Samuel 24:10).

questions.question: What was God's reaction to David's numbering of Israel?
options: God was displeased and smote Israel
questions.correctAnswer: God was displeased and smote Israel
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:7 states God was displeased and smote Israel, showing God's holiness and intolerance of sin (Isaiah 6:5; Romans 1:18). This also illustrates God's justice in punishing national sin (2 Chronicles 7:14).

questions.question: Which tribes did Joab exclude from the count, and why?
options: Levi and Benjamin, because the king's word was abominable to Joab
Judah and Simeon, because they were already counted
Ephraim and Manasseh, due to their size
Dan and Naphtali, because of their location
questions.correctAnswer: Levi and Benjamin, because the king's word was abominable to Joab
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:6 notes Joab did not count Levi and Benjamin because the king's command was abominable to him, reflecting the Levites' unique priestly role and the serious moral implications of the census (Numbers 1:47-53; Deuteronomy 7:6).

questions.question: What choice did the LORD offer David through Gad?
options: Three years famine, three months sword, or three days pestilence
Loss of kingdom, personal death, or family curse
questions.correctAnswer: Three years famine, three months sword, or three days pestilence
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:10-12 reveals God offered David three judgments, emphasizing divine mercy and justice, consistent with God's sovereign judgment in the Old Testament (Exodus 12:12; Jeremiah 24:10; 2 Samuel 24:13).

questions.question: What reason did David give for choosing to fall into the LORD's hands rather than men’s?
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD is merciful
questions.explanation: David’s choice in 1 Chronicles 21:13 shows his trust in God's mercy despite judgment, reflecting the biblical theme of God's compassion (Lamentations 3:22-23; Psalm 103:8; Micah 7:18).

questions.question: How many men died from the pestilence sent upon Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Seventy thousand
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:14 reports seventy thousand men died, illustrating the seriousness of sin and God’s righteous judgment (2 Samuel 24:15; Exodus 12:30; Numbers 25:9).

questions.question: Where did the angel of the LORD stop his destruction upon God’s repentance?
questions.correctAnswer: Threshingfloor of Ornan the Jebusite
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:15 indicates God repented and stayed the angel’s hand at Ornan’s threshingfloor, a place later significant in redemptive history (2 Samuel 24:16; 2 Chronicles 3:1).

questions.question: What was David’s response when he saw the angel with a drawn sword over Jerusalem?
options: He and the elders fell on their faces in sackcloth
He called for a military assembly
questions.correctAnswer: He and the elders fell on their faces in sackcloth
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:16 describes David and elders’ humble repentance, modeling contrition and prayer in the face of divine judgment (Joel 2:12-13; Psalm 51:17; Daniel 9:3).

questions.question: What did David ask God to do in place of punishing the people?
options: Let the punishment fall on him and his family
questions.correctAnswer: Let the punishment fall on him and his family
questions.explanation: In 1 Chronicles 21:17, David intercedes for the people, offering himself as substitute, a foreshadowing of Christ’s atonement (Isaiah 53:4-6; 2 Corinthians 5:21; Hebrews 9:28).

questions.question: What did the angel of the LORD command Gad to tell David to do?
options: Set up an altar to the LORD at Ornan’s threshingfloor
Build a new temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Set up an altar to the LORD at Ornan’s threshingfloor
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:18 directs David to build an altar at the threshingfloor, symbolizing repentance and restoration, connecting to themes of covenant and worship (Exodus 20:24; 2 Chronicles 3:1; Hebrews 13:10).

questions.question: How did Ornan respond to David’s request to buy the threshingfloor?
options: He offered it for free, including oxen and wheat
He asked David to pray first
questions.correctAnswer: He offered it for free, including oxen and wheat
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:23 shows Ornan’s generosity, but David insists on paying full price (verse 24), reflecting biblical principles of honest sacrifice (Leviticus 27:30; Proverbs 3:9).

questions.question: How much did David pay for the threshingfloor?
questions.correctAnswer: Six hundred shekels of gold
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:25 reports David paid six hundred shekels of gold, emphasizing the costliness of true worship and sacrifice (Exodus 30:13; 1 Kings 9:21).

questions.question: What was God's response to David's offering on the altar?
options: God answered by fire from heaven
God sent a prophet to rebuke David
questions.correctAnswer: God answered by fire from heaven
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:26 describes God accepting David’s sacrifice by sending fire, signifying divine approval consistent with Old Testament sacrificial acceptance (Leviticus 9:24; 1 Kings 18:38; Hebrews 12:28).

questions.question: Why could David not go before the tabernacle at Gibeon to inquire of God?
options: He was afraid because of the sword of the angel of the LORD
He was too busy with the plague
questions.correctAnswer: He was afraid because of the sword of the angel of the LORD
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 21:30 notes David’s fear due to the angel’s sword, showing reverence and awe before God's judgment, paralleling Moses' fear at God’s mountain (Exodus 3:6; Hebrews 12:29).
